entry.title: Agent builder in Joule Studio is now generally available: Build your own Joule agents today!
entry.content:
Traditional rule-based automation struggles to keep up with modern business processes, which are constantly evolving and becoming more complex. Agentic AI helps handle dynamic workflows with adaptability. As previewed at TechEd 2025, the agent builder capability in Joule Studio empowers developers to create context-aware Joule agents that can plan, reason, and execute multi-step processes across diverse systems, with self-learning and high adaptability, unlocking new levels of productivity and efficiency across your enterprise. 

Today, building on the release of skill builder in Joule Studio earlier in 2025, we’re excited to make the agent builder in Joule Studio generally available. The agent builder enables developers to create Joule agents that are tailored to their unique business requirements and break cross-ecosystem silos and reduce barriers to AI adoption. This capability is powered by the same underlying agent framework and runtime that ready-to-use Joule agents do. That offers built-in data protection guardrails, deep reasoning models, and context retention across tasks for scalable, secure multi-agent executions.  

In this post, I’ll take you through what’s being released as part of the agent builder experience, how to create Joule agents in no time, and resources to help you get started. We’ll explore common use cases to transform business workflows with agentic AI and provide visibility into our roadmap. Together, these insights will help you move from isolated AI experiments to scalable, production-grade agents that deliver real business impact. 

 Key highlights of the release: 

  • AI-guided development: Generate Joule Agents using natural language with vibe coding  
  • Model Context Protocol (MCP) support: Connect to external tools and applications with support for MCP 
  • Multi-agent orchestration: Add subagents as a tool to allow agents to invoke them for planning and executing complex, multi-step workflows 
  • Ground agents in business context: Drive reliable outcomes by grounding agent reasoning in your documents  
  • Leverage your existing SAP Build content: Embed pre-built custom skills, automations, and actions to accelerate time to value  
  • Human in the loop: ensure human oversight for critical decisions and approvals 

"With Joule Studio, agentic innovation moves closer to the heart of operations. At KPMG, we’re helping to shape trusted solutions that transform business context into measurable value by building specialized AI agents for fulfillment orchestration, supply chain management, and more”.  

 - Valentino Köster, Global Head of SAP360 Program & AI, KPMG AG WPG, Germany 

 

Meet Agent builder - the next evolution for Joule Studio  

Joule Studio is a capability in SAP Build that allows developers to design Joule agents and skills with a low code, no code canvas. Since it is part of SAP Build, Joule Studio has native access to all your connectors, automations, apps, and actions - enabling you to reuse artifacts, leverage shared APIs, and operate within a single governance framework. The agents created in Joule Studio work across their on-prem solutions including S/4 HANA and SAP ECC, SAP Cloud solutions, and third-party APIs and applications. Joule Studio leverages SAP Cloud Identity Services so that your agents have the right authorization and authentication for tasks that they are supposed to complete. It also enforces principal propagation, meaning the user’s identity in Joule is passed through end-to-end so that any triggered skill or agent runs strictly within that user’s security context, applying the same authorization checks and access restrictions. Moreover, it is integrated with Joule and AI core to seamlessly expose custom agents through Joule, empower agents with deep reasoning through models, and ground them in business data with document grounding.  

Image 1: Joule Studio Marketecture

 

Now let's dive into key features of agent builder in Joule Studio that simplifies the creation of powerful agents.

AI-guided development experience to fast-track deployment of AI agents 

Joule Studio brings AI guidance directly into the agent builder experience. Developers can describe what they need in plain language, and the Joule copilot responds with tailored suggestions for agent definitions, tools, and configuration options.  For instance, when building a logistics-focused agent, Joule may recommend a relevant Joule skill to fetch real-time stock levels and low-stock thresholds. This bridges the gap between simplicity and flexibility - empowering teams to innovate faster while maintaining full control over agent behavior.   

 

Image 2: AI-guided development for building agents in Joule Studio

 

Support for Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers for enhanced interoperability  

A major enhancement in Joule Studio is the newly added support for MCP - an open, standardized protocol that streamlines how AI agents interact with external systems. Instead of working within isolated applications, agents can now operate seamlessly across different platforms. 

In Joule Studio, you can connect agents to external MCP servers via destinations, configured in BTP Cockpit. That enables custom agents to tap into tools and services outside the SAP ecosystem. For instance, a support agent built in Joule Studio can create or update purchase requests in an external purchase requisition tool that exposes its capabilities via MCP. This level of interoperability turns AI agents into intelligent orchestrators that can handle end-to-end workflows across multiple systems without requiring custom integrations or heavy engineering effort. 

 

Image 3: Connecting custom Joule agents with third-party tools and applications using MCP

 

Creating multi-agent systems for complex workflows 

Joule Studio enables developers to build a modular “AI workforce” by allowing agents to be added as callable tools within other agents. Each agent can delegate tasks to specialized sub-agents built in Joule Studio and collaborate to solve much larger or more complex problems. This orchestration modularity avoids relying on a single, monolithic agent to handle everything and ensures clearer separation of responsibilities, simplifies testing and maintenance, and makes it far easier to scale agentic solutions as business needs evolve. 

For example, an “Inventory Restocking Agent” can act as an orchestrator and delegate tasks to specialized sub-agents such as a “Contract Compliance Checker” to validate that each proposed restocking order aligns with supplier contract terms before it is placed. These specialized sub-agents are built with Joule Studio and serve as reusable resources for other agents.  

Image 4: Adding other custom Joule agents built in Joule Studio as tools for other Joule agents 

From an idea to an agent in few simple steps 

Joule agents solve complex business challenges dynamically and intelligently. They excel in planning, reasoning, and autonomous execution, seamlessly navigating unknown paths with informed decision-making. Following are the key components of the agent definition:  

Goals and instructions: these act as job description for the agent and helps it understand its role and responsibilities  

Planning and reasoning: Large Language Models (LLMs) help agents plan and reason through the complex scenario   

Execution: agents need tools to interact with their environment and execute. 

Agent builder in Joule Studio allows designing a Joule agent with all the needed components in a low code/no code canvas that empowers both professional and citizen developers, allowing for scalability, governance, and alignment with SAP’s clean-core principles. 

The core steps include: 

  • Create a Project in SAP Build: Access SAP Build lobby and select project type for Joule Studio: ‘Joule agent and skill’. After filling out meta data for Joule Studio project, within that, create AI Agent as an artifact. 
  • Add Metadata: Assign name and description for the agent. This meta data helps Joule to identify the right agent for the job based on user intent. 
  • Define expertise and instructions: these provide the agent with context on its role and guide the agent’s behavior and decision-making. 
  • Configure tools: Select and configure the tools the agent can use to execute:  
  • MCP Servers: connect agents to external tools and applications exposed via MCP server, using destinations configured in BTP Cockpit. 
  • Sub agents as a tool: add other custom agents designed in Joule Studio as tools for one another, defining multi-agent systems for complex workflows. 
  • Joule skills: for executing rule-based, deterministic tasks 
  • Document grounding: create resource groups in AI Core with your business documents, then add those resource groups as tools to your agent in Joule Studio. This grounds agents in business context needed for a workflow. For example, adding carrier contracts to a logistic agent for making informed decisions on carriers for optimizing shipment transport. 
  • Human in the Loop: human oversight is ensured by default for critical decisions and compliance. 
  • Calculator: for mathematical calculations 
  • Testing: debug the agent in Joule Studio before deployment to see each step of its reasoning, actions and data flow, using mock conversations, tool-call scenarios and edge cases. 
  • Release and deploy: Once validated, deploy the agent into the designated environment, making it accessible to authorized users via Joule or other configured channels. 

This modular approach not only accelerates development but also embeds governance controls - such as tool usage boundaries and human-in-the-loop checkpoints - directly into the design process, ensuring enterprise-grade reliability and flexibility. See the demo below: 

 

“With Joule Studio, we could build powerful agents in three weeks. It is an intuitive, no‑code environment that enables system connectivity across SAP and non‑SAP critical environments, for a hybrid landscapes where data resides in multiple modules.”  

 - Gianluca Simeone, VP - Global SAP CTIO and Gen-AI Leader at Capgemini 

Use cases for custom Joule agents 

Joule agents are ideal for solving complex, dynamic problems that traditional automation come short in solving. They excel in scenarios where planning, reasoning, and adaptive execution are critical. Let’s explore some of common use cases for creating custom Joule agents: 

  • Payroll variance analysis: An agent can simplify payroll variance analysis, a critical process for financial control and compliance, by instantly determining the source of variances, confirming allowances align with company policies, andreducing resolution time. This provides managers and payroll specialists with visibility into deviations, ensuring accuracy and confidence in payroll operations. Read more. 
  • Customer purchasing behavior analysis: An agent can help sales representatives quickly identify anomalies in customer purchasing behavior and assist in responding proactively to improve customer experience. Read more 
  • Inventory management: An agent can enable manufacturers and retailers to reduce losses from aging and obsolete inventory by turning inventory management into a proactive, data-driven process. For example, an agent can scan SAP S/4HANA data to detect early signs of obsolescence, categorize risk, and suggest actions such as redistribution or markdowns. Read more. 
  • Q&A: An agent can interpret complex queries by retrieving accurate information instantly from enterprise systems, documents, and knowledge bases to surface the most relevant insights, and guide users step-by-step through processes. This reduces the dependency on manual lookups and helps users get the right answers quickly and consistently. Read more. 
  • Logistics: An agent can optimize delivery routes based on real-time traffic data, weather conditions, and carrier availability, enhancing efficiency and reducing transportation costs.  

“Nestle, SAP, and IBM worked together on a supply chain Agentic AI PoC. With the agent builder capability in Joule Studio, we created this POC bringing in data from SAP and non-SAP sources to create an agent that will automate our complex Order fulfillment processes”   

- Pablo Nill, Sr Product Group Manager, Nestle     

Image 5: Concept of a custom AI agent created to optimize logistics of a shipment

 

Looking ahead 

This is only the beginning. We’re working on bringing following new capabilities in the agent builder next year as part of our roadmap: 

  •  System-Triggered Agents: Enable agents to activate automatically based on system events, API triggers or schedule reducing manual intervention and accelerating workflows. 
  • Agent-to-Agent Collaboration (A2A): Allow agents to collaborate with third-party agents, coordinating tasks and sharing context for complex, multi-step processes. 
  • Agent Extensibility: Adapt ready-to-use Joule agents by adding tools and pre- and post-processing logic in an upgrade-safe way, ensuring flexibility without compromising stability. 

We’re running a limited-time promotion that lets your agents run at no cost until end of Jan 2026. Don't miss out on this opportunity and see following resources to help you get started: 

  • How to Get Started with Joule Studio 
  • Learn how to activate Joule Studio 
  • Joule Studio Goes Live: Answers to Your Top Questions 
  • Customer testimonial (Uniper) 
  • Watch the on-demand webinar for a deeper dive in agent builder 
  • Podcast 

Meanwhile, if you have any questions, contact our product experts: @Kvidit , @maria_kondratyeva , @soufia , @jenie , @shamichi , @eric_solberg , and @noravonthenen.

entry.title: Part 2: Building the Intelligent Maintenance Fulfillment Agent in Joule Studio
entry.content:
In my previous blog post, we laid the groundwork by creating, configuring, and deploying individual Joule Skills  (GetMaintenanceOrderDetails, GetOperationComponents, GetMaterialStockLevels, etc.) . These skills allow Joule to "talk" to our backend and perform specific tasks like fetching maintenance order details or checking material stock levels.However, a maintenance planner doesn't just want raw data; they want answers to complex questions like, "Can I finish this job today based on what's in the warehouse?" In this post, we move beyond individual skills. We will build a Joule Agent- the "brain" that orchestrates those skills to provide intelligent, end-to-end validation. 

Step 7: Create the Joule Agent Project 

  1. Go to your Joule Skill Project > Overview tab 
  2. Click Create > Joule Agent. 
  3. Fill in the following: 
    • Name: e.g., Maintenance Fulfillment Validator 
    • Identifier: maintenanceFulfillmentValidator 
    • Description: e.g., Agent to check if maintenance orders can proceed based on material stock levels .
  4. Click Create

Step 8: Add Expertise & Instructions 

After creation, you’ll land on the agent editor screen: 

Add a clear Expertise Summary to describe what your agent is good at (e.g., "Validating maintenance order fulfillment based on stock availability") 

In the Instructions section, define how the agent should behave: 

Step 9: Configure Model Settings & Tools 

Scroll down to the Model Settings section: 

  1. Choose your LLM Provider (e.g., SAP Joule Model or other available models) 
  2. Click Add Tool.

     

  3.  From the dropdown, select Joule Skill.
  4. You will now see a list of all the skills created in your project 
  5. Add all the relevant skills for your use case: 
    • GetMaintenanceOrderDetails 
    • GetOrderOperations 
    • GetOperationComponents 
    • GetMaterialDetails 
    • GetMaterialStockLevels 

 

Alternative Approach: Using Vibe Coding

Joule Studio offers an innovative capability called vibe coding that allows developers to define agents using natural language rather than manually wiring every step.

Instead of explicitly defining the orchestration logic, you describe the agent's goal, available skills, and constraints—and Joule Studio generates the agent flow for you. This makes vibe coding particularly useful for rapid prototyping, experimentation, and learning how agents reason across multiple skills.

In this section, we will recreate the same stock validation agent built earlier, but this time using vibe coding, to demonstrate how quickly an end-to-end agent can be assembled once the fundamentals are understood. 

Step 10: The "Vibe Coding" Alternative – Speed to Market 

  1. Open the Assistant: Click the Joule Chat icon inside the Agent Editor. 

     

  2. Prompt the Vibe:  "Create an agent that is able to validate maintenance orders, check material stock, and recommend actions to ensure fulfillment. 
    Include all available skills and use all the information you have (from the description and skills) to formulate expertise, fully describe the process in instructions and additional context.” 

     

  3. Confirm Generation: Joule generates the Instructions and Expertise automatically. It also suggests linking the Skills we built in Part 1. 
    1. Open the newly created agent in your project. 
    2. Review the Instructions and Expertise sections to confirm that Joule has generated a detailed, end-to-end logic for maintenance order validation. 
  4. Verify that the previously created skills are automatically added as Tools for the agent. 

     

  5. Refining the Vibe (Continuous Improvement): The true power of vibe coding is that you can iteratively add or refine your prompt based on what changes you need in your agent.
    1.  Iterative Improvement Example: Return to the Joule Chat assistant and provide additional refinement prompts: 
    2. Prompt 2 (Enhanced Instructions): "Update the current instructions of the Maintenance Fulfillment Agent to be highly detailed in each step. This includes requesting the order ID if not given, then extracting all information about the order including its operations. For each operation the components shall be extracted and verified by analyzing stock levels and details like open purchase orders, blocks etc. A fulfillment decision should be made depending on the analysis with a full explanation." 
    3. Review the Updates:Observe how Joule automatically updates the Instructions section with more granular step-by-step logic.

Step 11: Configure Skill Access Settings 

Regardless of whether you created your agent manually or through vibe coding, you need to configure how skills can be accessed: 

Important Configuration: 

  1. Navigate to each skill that your agent uses as a tool 
  2. Locate the toggle "Allow skill to be started directly by a user" 
  3. Ensure this toggle is turned OFF for all skills used by your agent 
  4. This configuration: 
    • Allows the agent to call skills programmatically 
    • Prevents direct user access to individual skills 
  5. Ensures users interact with the intelligent agent rather than raw skill outputs. 

     

Step 12: Test Your Agent (Before Deployment) 

Before deploying your agent to production, Joule Studio provides a built-in testing feature that allows you to validate your agent's functionality without deployment: 

  1. In the Agent Editor, locate the Test panel or Test button 

     

  2. Select your private environment which you can create in Environment in the control panel. 
  3. Click continue.

This opens an interactive testing interface within Joule Studio where you can ask your question to the agent.

Once you start testing your agent, you can observe how it intelligently orchestrates multiple skills to fulfill complex requests.

 

Example Prompts to Test the Agent 

  1. “Can order 25 be fulfilled with current stock?” 
  2. “What’s blocking maintenance order 20?” 
  3. “Is order 1 ready to proceed or does it need follow-up?” 
  4. “Why is order 4 still pending?” 
  5. “Which materials are causing delays in maintenance order 24?” 
  6. “Is material M-45678 available in stock?” 
  7. “How much of material M-98765 do we have?” 
  8. “Do we have enough materials for order with ID 10?” 

 

Step 13: Release, Version, and Deploy the Agent 

The deployment process for Joule Agents follows the same workflow as deploying Joule Skills. 

For detailed deployment steps, refer to "Step 6: Release and Deploy Joule Skills" from my previous blog post: How to Build Stock Validation Skills in Joule Studio 

Quick Summary: 

  1. Release: Click Release to version your agent 
  2. Navigate: Go to Project > Versions 
  3. Deploy: Click Deploy 
  4. Configure Deployment: 
    1. Select your Environment: Use the environment you created in Step 2 of the previous blog post 
    2. Select your Destination: Choose the appropriate destination 
    3. Ensure the destination is associated with your chosen environment 
  5. Confirm: Click Deploy 

The "Last Mile": Moving your Agent to Production 

Once your agent is Active, you’ll want to see it in action within the actual Joule Chat experience (e.g., in the BTP Cockpit or an SAP LoB application). To "productionize" your agent, follow these critical configuration steps: 

  1. Check your Formation: Ensure your BTP Formation is configured correctly in the BTP Cockpit and includes the necessary SAP LoB Application. 
  2. Enable Joule Shared: In the SAP Build app, navigate to the Environment level > Joule Tab. Under settings, enable Share Environment Capabilities. This allows the agent to be "seen" by the broader Joule tenant. 

     

  3. The Sync Window: After deploying to a shared environment, it typically takes about 30 minutes for the background synchronization to complete. 

Step 16: Advanced Integration - MCP Servers (Optional) 

For enterprise scenarios requiring external system integration beyond SAP, Joule Studio supports Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers as additional tools for your agent. 

What MCP Servers Enable: 

  • Connect to external APIs and third-party services 
  • Integrate with non-SAP databases and systems 
  • Build cross-system orchestration workflows 
  • Extend agent capabilities beyond SAP ecosystem 

High-Level Setup Process: 

  1. BTP Configuration: Create and configure MCP server destinations in your BTP Cockpit 
  2. Joule Studio Integration: Add the configured destinations to your Joule Studio environment 
  3. Agent Integration: Reference MCP servers in your agent alongside Joule Skills 

Wrapping Up Part 2: From Skills to Intelligent Orchestration 

In this second part of our Joule Studio blog , we've elevated individual skills into an intelligent agent that can orchestrate multiple capabilities seamlessly. Your Maintenance Fulfillment Validator agent now understands complex maintenance scenarios, coordinates between different skills, and provides comprehensive responses about order fulfillment and stock validation. 

Key Achievements: 

  • Traditional Agent Building: Step-by-step manual configuration of expertise, instructions, and skill orchestration 
  • Vibe Coding Innovation: Rapid agent creation using natural language prompts - demonstrating how Joule Studio can automatically generate agent logic, expertise, and instructions 
  • Multi-Skill Orchestration: Your agent intelligently coordinates multiple skills to provide holistic business insights 

Vibe Coding Advantage: The introduction of vibe coding shows how Joule Studio is evolving to accelerate development cycles. What traditionally required manual configuration can now be achieved through conversational AI, making agent development more accessible and faster. 

With both individual skills, intelligent agents, and rapid prototyping capabilities in your toolkit, you're now equipped to build sophisticated automation solutions that can handle complex business scenarios with human-like intelligence. 

Looking Ahead: The Future of Joule Studio Agents 

As Joule Studio continues to evolve, exciting capabilities are on the roadmap that will further transform how businesses leverage AI automation: 

  • Agent-to-Agent (A2A) Communication: Enabling agents to collaborate and coordinate with each other for complex multi-domain workflows 
  • Agent Extensibility: Advanced customization capabilities allowing deeper integration with your specific business processes 
  • System-Triggered Agents: Proactive agents that respond automatically to business events and system triggers, moving beyond user-initiated interactions 

The foundation you've built today positions you perfectly to leverage these advanced capabilities as they become available, creating even more sophisticated and autonomous business solutions. 

Learning Resources

  • How to Get Started with Joule Studio 
  • Learn how to activate Joule Studio 
  • Setting Up Joule Studio for All Customer Flows and Entitlement Levels
  • Joule Studio Goes Live: Answers to Your Top Questions 
  • Customer testimonial (Uniper) 
  • Watch the on-demand webinar for a deeper dive in agent builder 
  • Podcast

entry.title: 6 Steps to an AI Assessment in SAP: Discovery-First Approach
entry.content:
As Technical Architect we are supposed to pull out the rabbit from the hat, everytime you are in a conversation of AI with respect to SAP IT Estate. Am sharing my approach with the community on how we are exploring this 'Discovery' phase without falling into the trap of 'how will I implement it'.

With the evolution of SAP S/4HANA and the increasing maturity of SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), Artificial Intelligence is no longer an external add-on to SAP landscapes. SAP has embedded AI capabilities directly into its core through services such as SAP AI Core, AI Launchpad, Joule, embedded machine learning in S/4HANA, and intelligent process automation on BTP. As a result, organizations are no longer asking whether AI is relevant to SAP, but where and how it can deliver measurable value.

Despite this progress, many AI initiatives in SAP environments struggle to move beyond pilots. A common root cause is the absence of a structured AI discovery phase that is aligned with SAP business processes, data structures, and enterprise operating models. Before leveraging SAP’s built-in AI capabilities or extending them through BTP, organizations must first identify the 'right' AI use cases.

This article outlines a six-step AI assessment approach I use to focused exclusively on discovery, designed to help SAP consultants and system integrators systematically identify and prioritize AI use cases in S/4HANA-centric landscapes. The approach is technology-aware but implementation-agnostic, ensuring that discovery outcomes remain valid regardless of deployment choices.

Step 1: Frame the AI Assessment Scope in an S/4HANA Landscape

The foundation of an effective AI assessment is a clearly defined scope. In SAP environments, this typically includes S/4HANA application areas such as Finance, Supply Chain, Manufacturing, Sales, Asset Management, and Human Resources, along with adjacent systems integrated via SAP BTP.

At this stage, the objective is not to assess SAP AI Core configurations or BTP services, but to establish 'where' AI exploration is relevant. Business capability maps, value streams, or process hierarchies are particularly effective inputs, as they provide a stable abstraction independent of system customizations.

Equally important is explicitly positioning the assessment as discovery-only. No architectural decisions, tool comparisons, or implementation commitments should be made. This constraint preserves neutrality and ensures that use cases are driven by business need rather than platform bias.

The cheat an architect can use here is to think of all possibilities and not to get into the trap of thinking how one will implement to solution.

Step 2: Map Business Capabilities to S/4HANA Processes

AI use cases in SAP emerge at the intersection of business capabilities and S/4HANA processes. Therefore, the next step is to map enterprise capabilities—such as Forecast-to-Stock or Hire-to-Retire—to the underlying S/4HANA processes and transactional flows that realize them.

This mapping shifts the discussion away from modules and transactions toward business outcomes. It also highlights areas where standard S/4HANA processes are supplemented by manual activities, spreadsheets, or external decision-making—common indicators of AI opportunity.

For system integrators, this step is particularly valuable, as it anchors AI discovery in SAP-standard process models while still accommodating client-specific variations.

The cheat an architect can use here is to hghlight data-heavy or repetitive processes and identify high touchpoint sub processes.

Step 3: Identify AI Opportunities Using SAP-Relevant Heuristics

With process mapping in place, AI discovery heuristics are applied to identify candidate use cases. In S/4HANA landscapes, these heuristics align closely with scenarios already supported or extensible through SAP AI services.

Processes characterized by high manual effort, frequent exceptions, or repetitive validations often indicate opportunities for intelligent automation. Decision-intensive processes, such as demand planning, cash forecasting, or risk assessment, suggest predictive or optimization use cases. Classification-heavy activities—including document processing, master data enrichment, and service ticket categorization—are well suited for machine learning approaches. Conversational scenarios emerge where users require natural-language access to SAP data or procedural knowledge.

The cheat an architect can use here is to look into the historical data, system logs, process mining data, time and motions study data to form a baseline. Applying these ideas consistently ensures that AI use cases are identified systematically rather than opportunistically.

Step 4: Score Opportunities - Qualitatively Assess Value, Feasibility, and Adoption Readiness

Discovery requires prioritization, but prioritization during this phase should remain lightweight and qualitative. Each identified AI use case is assessed across three dimensions.

Business value reflects the potential impact on efficiency, cost, compliance, or decision quality. Feasibility considers data availability within S/4HANA, integration complexity, and alignment with existing automation or BTP usage. Adoption readiness evaluates organizational factors such as user acceptance, process ownership, and change impact.

The architect needs to check the technology readiness only at this stage. Identify the technology stack, check availability, and what is needed to be procured. 

The cheat for an architect here is that this assessment is comparative rather than absolute. The goal is not to build a business case, but to distinguish high-potential use cases from those that are premature or misaligned.

 Step 5: Build an AI Impact Heatmap for SAP Processes

The outputs of the assessment are consolidated into an AI impact heatmap, which serves as the primary deliverable of the discovery phase. The heatmap visualizes AI use cases across SAP processes against dimensions such as value and feasibility.

Use cases positioned in the high-value, high-feasibility quadrant typically represent strong candidates for subsequent proof-of-concept initiatives using SAP AI Core or BTP services. High-value but lower-feasibility cases are documented as strategic backlog items, often dependent on data quality or process standardization improvements. Low-impact cases are consciously deprioritized.

For SAP programs, the heatmap provides a shared language between business stakeholders, functional consultants, and technical architects.

The cheat an architect can use here is to identify high-value use cases with feasible technology, data & integration.

Step 6: Select Discovery Candidates

The final step of discovery is to consolidate findings into a short list of prioritized AI use cases, usually limited to three to five candidates. These use cases should demonstrate clear business relevance, alignment with S/4HANA processes, and reasonable feasibility within the current SAP landscape.

Common examples identified during SAP AI discovery include intelligent invoice processing, predictive MRP, conversational assistants for SAP user support, and automated sales order validation. However, the true value of discovery lies in identifying 'context-specific' opportunities rather than replicating generic patterns.

At this point, the AI assessment concludes. Any further activities—such as solution architecture, SAP AI Core enablement, or BTP service selection—belong to subsequent phases and should be initiated only after stakeholder alignment on discovery outcomes.

The cheat for an architect is to Identify the 3-5 discovery candidate​, that can be delivered in the first sprint successfully. The exploratory 'fail fast' cases should be put for later sprints.

To surmise, as SAP continues to embed AI capabilities into S/4HANA and SAP BTP, the success of enterprise AI initiatives increasingly depends on disciplined discovery rather than experimental implementation. A structured, discovery-first AI assessment enables organizations to align AI use cases with SAP business processes, data realities, and organizational readiness. Joule will accelerate the SAP AI adaptations through its customer base.

For SAP Enterprise Architects, this six-step Discovery-First approach provides a repeatable and scalable framework that complements S/4HANA transformations and positions SAP’s built-in AI capabilities for sustainable value realization.

entry.title: Generate Client Certificate for Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities via SAP BTP
entry.content:
Prerequisites:

  1. Access to the relevant subaccount in which you want to generate a certificate.
  2.  Admin privileges for the SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition system.

Generate Client Certificate 

  1. In your SAP BTP Subaccount, navigate to Connectivity ➡️ Destination Certificates ➡️ click on Create
  2. Under the Generation Method section, choose External service

  3. Under the Generation Details, fill in the following fields:
    1. Name – The name you would like to assign to the certificate.
    2. File Extension – Leave this field as is, with the value PEM.
    3. Validity – Select the desired duration; I chose one year.
    4. Password – Although this field is optional, it is required to complete the installation in the system.
    5. Automatic Renewal – Set according to your preference; the default value is "On".
  4.  Click on Create.
  5. You will get the following screen:

Download the Client Certificate 

To download the certificate we generated along with its private key, we’ll need to use the Destination Service (Cloud Foundry) API.
The full certificate isn’t available for download through the SAP BTP admin console.
 
You can find the full API documentation on: https://api.sap.com/api/SAP_CP_CF_Connectivity_Destination/overview 

The API URL is: https://destination-configuration.cfapps.<your_region>.hana.ondemand.com/destination configuration/v1/subaccountCertificates
 
In my example, the region is eu10.
 

For authentication, we need to create an instance of the Destination Service and generate a service key if one does not already exist in our subaccount.

  1. Create a Destension service instance for the authentication details:
    1. In your SAP BTP Subaccount, navigate to Services ➡️ Instances and Subscription ➡️ click on Create.
    2.  Choose the "Destination Service" service, select the "lite" plan, and use a space you have authorization to create an instance in ➡️ click on Create.
    3. After creation, you will see a new instance 
    4. Create a new service key, enter the Service Key Name ➡️ Create.
       

    5. Click on ... ➡️ View
       
The authentication method required for this API is Bearer token authentication.
In my example, I use the Postman client, but you can also work with any other API tool that supports OAuth 2.0 authentication.
 
For the authentication with OAuth 2.0, enter the following fields (when using Pastman):
  1. Grant Type = "Client Credentials" 
  2. Access Token URL = "url" in our service key JSON file with the prefix "/oauth/token"
  3. Client ID = "clientid" in our service key JSON file.
  4. Client Secret = "clientsecret" in our service key JSON file.
  5. Client Authentication = "Send as Basic Auth header".
  6. Click on Get New Access Token ➡️ on the new pop-up window click on Use Token

After we have a token, we can call the API to get our certificate:

The method is GET, and the URL will be https://destination-configuration.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/destination-configuration/v1/subaccountCertificates/{Your Certificate Name}.

In my example, the URL will be: https://destination-configuration.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/destination-configuration/v1/subaccountCertificates/J4D_Guide.pem.

The response for the call needs to be like:   

We will get the full certificate, including the private key in base64, and now we need to convert it to text and save it as a PEM certificate.

 
For the conversion, I'm using the terminal on my computer with the command:
echo "base64string" | base64 --decode​

You will need to replace the "base64string" with your certificate in base64.

The decoded result will be like the example below:

I copied the full result to a text editor and saved it with the PEM extension. 

Load the Client Certificate to the SAP S/4HANA private cloud 

After we have the PEM certificate with the private key, we can proceed and load the certificate to the ABAP system.

  1. Enter the "STRUST" transaction ➡️ on the top toolbar, and click on "Environment" ➡️ and choose "SSL Client Identities of System "

     

  2.  ➡️ Click on the change button. 
  3. Click on "New Entries" ➡️ Enter an Identity and Desctiption ➡️ Click Enter ➡️ Click on Save.
  4. You will need a transport request to save the changes, so create a new one.
  5. The new entry will appear on the left panel
  6. If you are in display mode, click on the change button. once again.
  7. On the top toolbar, click on PSE ➡️  Import ➡️ PKCS#8/PEM 
  8. In the file browser, choose the file you created in the previous step.
  9. Enter the certification password as entered in the SAP BTP admin portal.
  10. You will see the certificate details:
  11. Click on the check mark to proceed to the next step.
  12. On the top toolbar, click on PSE ➡️ ➡️ Save As...
  13. On the pop-up, choose the SSL Client with the client we created before ➡️ Click on the check mark 
  14. Click on the Save button on the toolbar.

We’re done 😊
Now all that remains is to import the certificates from the BTP Trust Store and continue configuring Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities.

entry.title: Use Custom Roles with Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Introduction: With the increasing adoption of Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition (PCE), customers are now looking beyond standard business roles and want to control access using custom roles. This becomes especially important when Joule is enabled for selective users, specific business scenarios, or restricted transactional access.

However, configuring custom roles for Joule is not entirely straightforward. It requires a clear understanding of role content, content exposure, and identity provisioning, all of which must work together to ensure Joule can access the required business data and applications.

In this blog, I will walk you through three key topics that will help you successfully use custom roles with Joule in SAP S/4HANA PCE:

1️. What a Custom Role Must Contain for Joule to Work Correctly

When using custom roles with Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, the role definition plays a critical role in determining what Joule can see, understand, and execute. Unlike traditional Fiori usage, Joule depends heavily on Launchpad content, semantic navigation, and backend OData access.

Below are the three key aspects you must consider while designing a custom role.

When creating a custom role, it is essential to ensure that it contains the required semantic objects and Fiori app IDs. You can check this SAP Note for the required semantic objects and Fiori app IDs.

To verify this, you should always check the business catalogs that are assigned to your custom role. Business catalogs define which applications, semantic objects, and target mappings are available to the user - and these are what Joule relies on for navigation and execution.

For example, in this scenario, I created a single custom role by reusing a standard SAP business catalog that already contains all Purchase Order related semantic objects and Fiori app IDs.

 

By including this required semantic objects and Fiori app IDs in the custom role, Joule can correctly:

  • Resolve Purchase Order related intents
  • Navigate using the appropriate semantic object and action
  • Launch the correct Fiori applications without additional configuration

If you plan to use a Master Role and Derived Role approach, you can create the master role in the same way as described above, ensuring it contains all the required business catalogs, semantic objects, and Fiori app IDs.

Once the master role is created, you can then derive one or more derived roles from it. The derived roles inherit all the authorization content from the master role, while allowing you to maintain organizational-level restrictions if required.

I have also created a derived role from the master role, as shown in the screenshot below. The derived role inherits all the required business catalogs, semantic objects, and Fiori app mappings from the master role, ensuring consistent access behavior for Joule while allowing role assignment at the user level.

2️. How to Perform Content Exposure for Custom Roles

🔹V2 Content Exposure (Recommended)

If you are on SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition 2023 FPS01 or higher, you must expose your content using Content Exposure Version 2 (V2).

Before exposing content, ensure the following prerequisites are in place.

🔹Activate Required ICF Services

Make sure the following ICF service is active:

  • /sap/bc/http

You can verify and activate this using transaction SICF.

🔹Maintain Design-Time Destination in SAP BTP

In SAP BTP, the design-time destination must include the following service endpoint URL:

<host>/sap/bc/http/ui2/flp_content_exposure/entities

This endpoint is required for SAP Build Work Zone to read exposed content from S/4HANA.

🔹Activate HTTP Service via UCON

Since this is an HTTP-based service, it may need explicit activation.

  • Use transaction UCON_HTTP_SERVICES
  • Activate the service:
  • /UI2/FLP_CONTENT_EXPOSURE

This step is mandatory if the service is restricted by UCON.

🔹Required Authorization Roles

Ensure the following roles are assigned:

  • Administrator Role
    The administrator must have SAP Fiori Launchpad administration authorizations to expose content to SAP BTP.
  • SAP_FLP_EXP_USER
    Assign this role to the technical user used by SAP Build Work Zone.
    This role allows the user to read and consume exposed content.

🔹Which Roles Should Be Exposed?

To expose roles, use transaction:

/UI2/CDM3_EXP_SCOPE

Perform the following steps:

  1. Choose Exposure Version = Version 2
  2. Select roles under Areas
    • All selected roles across areas will be exposed
    • You can expose individual roles or group multiple roles under one area

Role Exposure Rules

  • Custom Single Role
    → Directly expose the custom role
  • Master & Derived Role Model
    → Expose the Master Role only
    (Derived roles cannot be exposed independently)
  • Alternative Approach
    If you do not want to expose the master role:
    • Create a Composite Role
    • Add the required derived roles
    • Expose the composite role

This approach provides flexibility while keeping role design clean.

🔹Verification Steps to Ensure Joule Can Consume the Content

Once the content exposure is completed:

  1. Go to SAP Build Work Zone
  2. Perform a content refresh / update

  3. Verify that:
    • Exposed apps are visible
    • Semantic navigation works
    • Apps can be launched from Work Zone

If the content is visible and accessible in SAP Build Work Zone, Joule will be able to consume and use the exposed content correctly.

3️. How to Set Up Identity Provisioning (IPS) to Test Custom Roles

Finally, to validate custom roles with Joule, you must configure the Identity Provisioning Service (IPS) job so that users and roles from SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition are provisioned correctly to SAP Build Work Zone.

In most productive systems, executing a full IPS job can take a significant amount of time, as it processes all users and all roles available in the source S/4HANA PCE system. For testing and validation purposes, it is recommended to limit the scope of provisioning using filters.

🔹Why Use Filters in IPS?

By applying filters, you can:

  • Provision only specific test users
  • Provision only relevant custom roles
  • Reduce job execution time

🔹Recommended IPS Filters for Testing

In the IPS source system configuration, add the following filters.

Role Filter

Use this filter to provision only the required custom roles.

abap.role.name.filter = (?i)^(ROLE1|ROLE2|ROLE3).*

🔹This filter:

  • Is case-insensitive ((?i))
  • Provisions only roles matching the specified role names

If you are using a Master and Derived Role model and assign derived roles to users, then you must maintain only the derived roles in this filter. Master roles should not be included unless they are directly assigned to users.

User Filter

Use this filter to provision only the test users.

abap.user.name.filter = ^(USER1|USER2|USER3).*

🔹Execute and Validate the IPS Job

After maintaining the filters:

  1. Run the IPS job
  2. Monitor the job status for errors
  3. Verify in SAP Build Work Zone that:
    • Test users are provisioned
    • Correct roles are assigned

  4. Log in as a test user and validate Joule behavior

If the users and roles are visible and correctly assigned in SAP Build Work Zone, Joule will be able to consume the exposed content and execute actions as expected.

entry.title: SAP Joule Extensibility - With Joule Studio Skill Builder
entry.content:
During TechEd, AI was a central theme across nearly all sessions — it was rare to find one where the term “AI” wasn’t mentioned. Many of these sessions focused on Joule agents, skills, and the Agent Builder, which is expected to be released by the end of December 2025.

That said, Joule Studio is already available today as part of Build Process Automation. In addition to the upcoming Agent Builder, it is currently possible to extend Joule’s capabilities using Custom Joule Skills through the Joule Skill Builder.

To put it simply, we are still running S/4HANA 2022 FPS02, and features such as Sales Order Fulfillment and Monitoring (SAP Note 3459573) via Joule are only available in later releases. As a result, asking Joule transactional questions related to Sales Orders does not yield any response.

Here’s where the Joule Skill Builder in Joule Studio comes into play.

We could create a custom skill and leverage existing BAPIs in the S/4HANA system. (First, a destination must be configured in the BPA BTP subaccount to establish the connection with the S/4 system.)

Once the S/4 system is accessible from BPA via this destination, the next step is to define actions—specifying which fields, tasks, and data should be retrieved from S/4 using the relevant BAPIs (in this case, those related to Sales Orders).

The only mandatory input field required is the Sales Document Number; all other fields have been excluded from the selection.

The following are the only output fields (or outputs) of interest for this Joule Skill.

Once the Action is defined, we’re ready to build our first basic Joule Skill. I’ll include a few numbered screenshots to illustrate the process and explain the overall flow.

 

Once the skill is deployed in your BPA environment, you can grant and share access to other users using the Share option. To test the skill, simply launch the standalone Joule using the Launch button.

The skill can also be deployed and made available to the central/shared Joule instance that is enabled across the SAP landscape, encompassing both private and public cloud systems and services (via Joule Formation).

Now we can retry the same Sales Order queries to check if Joule can provide meaningful responses. This time, I invoked Joule directly from our S/4HANA system, rather than launching it as a standalone instance from BPA.

Although this functionality is not natively supported in the S/4HANA version we are currently running, we successfully extended Joule’s capabilities by creating custom skills to address a simple, practical use case.

Disclaimer: An additional skill was also developed to demonstrate the Card with Buttons feature; however, it is not covered here 🙂

Helpful Links

How to Get Started with Joule Studio

Set Up Joule Studio

Mission in Discovery Center

entry.title: SAP Joule Document Grounding (Business AI)
entry.content:
t’s finally time to explore Document Grounding and train Joule to answer questions using your company’s specific policy and knowledge documents. But before diving into Joule, it’s important to first understand Retrieval Augmented Generation.

 

  • Retrieval: When you ask a question, the system first searches a database, documents, or knowledge source (like a company’s files, research papers) for the relevant information.
  • Augmentation: Those retrieved documents are passed into the language model as extra context.
  • Generation: The model then uses both its own knowledge and the retrieved information to produce an answer that is more accurate and grounded in facts.

 

This helps reduce hallucinations (when an AI makes things up) and allows the model to answer questions about data it wasn’t originally trained on.

In line with the general SAP documentation approach, we used SharePoint as the content ingestion platform. This means that once you create and execute a data pipeline, documents from your selected SharePoint sites and folders are successfully ingested into the pipeline. After ingestion, Joule can leverage this information to augment its responses.

The setup is technically intensive. For those interested in testing this out—and to avoid overloading this post with technical jargon—the SAP TechEd session on Setting up Joule to answer questions in your own policy documents is the best starting point.

We used Bruno as the tool to setup a data pipeline between SharePoint and BTP subaccount running Joule.

 

Below are a couple of examples where we set up a data pipeline to make Joule aware of Kardex (Kardex is an Automatic Storage Retrieval System). We also ingested specific HR policy documents.

As a result, when queried, Joule is contextually aware of this information and provides grounded responses specific to this knowledge base.

 

Be prepared for some issues and challenges during the deployment along the way and reference this great post " Joule – Getting Started with Document Grounding"to solve some of them

Pre-Requisites for using Joule Document Grounding:

  • You’ve purchased the AI Unit SKU (8019164) and AI units.
  • You’ve added the entitlements for document grounding to the subaccount where you’ve subscribed to Joule.
  • You’ve enabled Identity Authentication with Cloud Identity Services

entry.title: Hands-On Guide: SAP Build + Joule Skill for Purchase Order Listing, Approval, or Modification
entry.content:
Introduction

In this tutorial, we will build an AI powered Purchase Order listing, modification or approval app using SAP Build and Joule. This step by step guide covers everything from OData integration to creating a working Joule Skill.

 

Table of Contents

  • 1. Create an Environment
  • 2. Exposing the Destination
  • 3. Create a database table to store purchase orders
  • 4. Create a CDS from the ZTABLE for Odata
  • 5. Create OData service with T-code SEGW
  • 6. Activate the Odata service via /iwfnd/maint_service T-code
  • 7. Crete an Action in SAP Build
  • 8. Create A Joule Skill to Get Purchase Order
  • 9. Create A Joule Skill to Approve Purchase Order
  • 10. Launch The Joule and Test The Skills

 

 

In today’s SAP ecosystem, intelligent automation is an expectation, not a future goal. SAP Build allows developers to quickly create business applications without extensive coding and SAP Joule brings AI-driven intelligence to these experiences.

In this hands-on guide, I’ll walk you through the process of building a Joule skill that connects to an OData service, allowing users to list, approve, and update purchase orders directly through SAP Build. ( This guide uses ZTABLE to store purchase order data because the standard SAP tables in the test system I work on don't have enough or the right kind of data. However, you can use the standard tables instead of ZTABLE. )

This project shows how AI capabilities can seamlessly integrate into SAP’s low-code environment, enabling automation and human decision-making in one interface. Whether you want to enhance your workflow with intelligent actions or explore real-world Joule integration scenarios, this guide will provide a practical starting point.

 

1. Create an Environment

 

We need to create an environment for testing joule skill.

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Environments and press the Create button.

 

 

Name your environment and add Description.

 

2. Exposing the Destination

 

Url of the destination on BTP is the url of our SAP system and the destination must have these properties: 

sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled -> true

sap.processautomation.enabled -> true

sap.build.usage -> odata_gen

 

Also the destination’s user will be used for set an external break-point for debugging the ABAP code.

 

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Destinations and press the Add button.

 

Select the Destination and choose next.

 

Choose the environment in which you want to use the target. For this tutorial you can choose the Test Environment that you create.

 

3. Create a database table to store purchase orders

@EndUserText.label : 'Purchase Order Change With Sap Build'
@AbapCatalog.enhancementCategory : #NOT_CLASSIFIED
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table zbg_build_test {
  key mandt                      : mandt not null;
  key purchaseorder              : ebeln not null;
  key purchaseorderitem          : ebelp not null;
  key reservationitem            : ebelp not null;
  material                       : matnr;
  materialcompisvariablesized    : boolean;
  materialcomponentisphantomitem : boolean;
  reservation                    : char10;
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zbg_build_test.entryunit'
  requiredquantity               : menge_d;
  requirementdate                : dats;
  reservationisfinallyissued     : boolean;
  baseunit                       : meins;
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zbg_build_test.entryunit'
  quantityinentryunit            : menge_d;
  entryunit                      : meins;
  plant                          : werks_d;
  latestrequirementdate          : dats;
  billofmaterialitemnumber       : ebelp;
  bomitemcategory                : char1;
  isbulkmaterialcomponent        : boolean;
  debitcreditcode                : shkzg;
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zbg_build_test.entryunit'
  withdrawnquantity              : menge_d;
  approver                       : uname;
  appoved                        : flag;

}

 

Fill the table:

 

 

4. Create a CDS from the ZTABLE for Odata

 

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSLV_BUILD_TST_V'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Purchasing Document Informations CDS'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.deleteEnabled: true
@ObjectModel.createEnabled: true
@ObjectModel.updateEnabled: true
define view ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST as select from zbg_build_test as z 
    
{   @EndUserText.label: 'Purchase Order'
    key purchaseorder,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Purchase Order Item'
    key purchaseorderitem,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Reservation Item'
    key reservationitem,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Material'
    material,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Material Size'
    materialcompisvariablesized,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Material Item'
    materialcomponentisphantomitem,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Reservation'
    reservation,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Quantity'
    requiredquantity,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Date'
    requirementdate,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Reservation Issue'
    reservationisfinallyissued,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Unit'
    baseunit,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Entry Unit'
    entryunit,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Quantity In Entry Unit'
    quantityinentryunit,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Plant'
    plant,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Latest Requirement Date'
    latestrequirementdate,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Bill Of Material Number'
    billofmaterialitemnumber,
    @EndUserText.label: 'BOM Item Category'
    bomitemcategory,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Is Bulk Material'
    isbulkmaterialcomponent,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Debit Credit Code'
    debitcreditcode,
    @EndUserText.label: 'With Drawn Quantity'
    withdrawnquantity,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Approver'
    approver,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Approved'
    appoved 
    
}

 

5. Create OData service with T-code SEGW

(Because of the version of the system I work on, this guide uses SEGW instead of RAP to create an OData service. However, you can easily create your own OData service with RAP.)

Press ‘Create Project’ button, fill the fields and assign the package, request (For this tutorial it will be local object).

 

Complete the creation.

 

Extend the project, right click to ‘Data Model’, select the Reference->Source

 

 

Fill the CDS name that you created. Choose ‘Next’.

 

 

Choose ‘Finish’.

 

 

Activate and generate the Service:

 

 

Go to the class ZCL_ZSLV_BUILD_DPC_EXT. At the bottom of the method list redefine the update method ZSLV_V_BUILD_TES_UPDATE_ENTITY.

 

 

In the method, update the approved field with the below code and activate it.

 

METHOD zslv_v_build_tes_update_entity.
 
  DATA: lv_ebeln TYPE ebeln,
        lv_ebelp TYPE ebelp,
        lv_item  TYPE ebelp,
        ls_entity TYPE zcl_zslv_build_mpc=>ts_zslv_v_build_testtype,
        lr_entity TYPE REF TO data,
        ls_table TYPE zbg_build_test.
 
  LOOP AT it_key_tab INTO DATA(ls_key).
    CASE ls_key-name.
      WHEN 'purchaseorder'.
        lv_ebeln = ls_key-value.
      WHEN 'purchaseorderitem'.
        lv_ebelp = ls_key-value.
      WHEN 'reservationitem'.
        lv_item = ls_key-value.
    ENDCASE.
  ENDLOOP.
 
  io_data_provider->read_entry_data( IMPORTING es_data = ls_entity ).
  MOVE-CORRESPONDING ls_entity TO ls_table.
  er_entity = ls_entity.
  UPDATE zbg_build_test FROM ls_table.
  COMMIT WORK.
 
ENDMETHOD.

 

6. Activate the Odata service via /iwfnd/maint_service T-code

 

Choose ‘Add Service’

 

 

Select the ‘System Alias’, fill the ‘Technical Service Name’ and press ‘Get Services’. Select the service that you create and press ‘Add Selected Services’.

 

 

Assign the package and continue.

 

 

We have added the service, which should appear as follows. In the ICF Nodes section, there is a button labeled "SAP Gateway Client" that provides a testing environment for the service. Press that button.

 

 

Select the HTTP method as ‘GET’. Press ‘EntitySets’ to choose entity set. Choose the one that you created.

 

 

Press ‘Execute’ button for testing and response should appear as follows.

 

 

7. Crete an Action in SAP Build

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Connectors->Actions and press the ‘Create’ button. Choose ‘OData Destinations’ and select the Destination that we created.

 

 

Fill the Resource Path as follows and click ‘Next’.

 

 

The available methods are listed in this window. Select ‘Next’.

 

 

Fill the name and description for your action and create.

 

 

The action Purchase_Order_Action is created. Click the action and open it.

 

 

Select the methods in the OData Service.

 

 

The GET method's input has no required fields, only optional GET parameters.

 

 

Output parameters are the fields in the CDS that we created. 

 

 

Methods can be tested in the action interface. For the GET method we don’t need to fill any input parameters. Click ‘Test’ button.

 

 

The data appears on the ‘Test Preview’ section.

 

 

The PATCH method requires purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem, all of which are key fields in our ZTABLE and CDS.

 

 

There are no standard output in PATCH method.

 

 

In the Test section, all required fields and fields that need to be changed must be filled out. In this scenario these fields are purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem, reservationitem and approved fields.

 

Also the link on the Test section can be used in the SAP Gateway Client to test the PATCH method.

 

 

 

PATCH method return “204: NO CONTENT” and empty Response. This means the update is successful and we will use this emptiness in our joule skill.

 

 

After checking and testing, save the methods using the ‘Save’ button and select ‘Release’. After the release process, the action should appear as shown below. Then, press 'Publish'.

 

 

You can debug when testing methods via the SAP Gateway Client or the SAP Build Action. Set an external breakpoint for the user in your destination that we created at the beginning.

 

 

For the PATCH method, our key fields in the internal table IT_KEY_TAB. 

 

 

8. Create A Joule Skill to Get Purchase Order

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Create->Joule Skill and fill the name and description. Open the created skill.

 

 

Select the ’Trigger’ step. On the ‘General’ tab fill the name and description. Allow Joule to generate a response and skill to be started directly by user.

 

 

We don't need input, but outputs can vary according to our needs. In this tutorial, the parameters shown below have been added as outputs.

Choose ‘Configure’ and add parameters you want to show to the user. For this example, all parameters are string except the ‘approved’ which is boolean.

 

 

 

Press ‘+’ and choose ‘Call Action’, ‘Browse All Actions’.

 

 

Search for ‘ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST’ or your Service Name. Add the ‘Get entities from ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST’.

 

 

Select the ‘Destination Variable’ as Destination we created. 

 

 

We can skip the input tab because there are no input for GET method.

 

 

We can see the output parameters in this tab.

 

 

On the "End" step, we need to assign the input and output parameters for the skills. Since we don't have any inputs, let's assign the outputs added in the "Trigger" step as our action's outputs.

 

 

Save the Joule Skill.

 

 

And Release.

 

 

Now Deploy.

 

 

Choose the Environment we created and click ‘Upgrade’.

 

 

Match the destinations, and the skill will be ready to use by Joule after deployment.

 

 

9. Create A Joule Skill to Approve Purchase Order

 

On the ‘Trigger’ step, fill the name and description. Deactivate the ‘Allow Joule to generate a response’ feature because in this skill we will create our own messages. The other feature should be active.

 

 

Configure the input parameters. Add purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem key fields as string. For approve skill we don’t need any output field.

 

 

Choose ‘+’ and ‘Call Action’.

 

 

Browse All Actions.

 

 

Search update or the service name. Add the Update entity in ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST.

 

 

On the ‘General’ tab, assign the Destination.

 

 

On the ‘Inputs’ tab, assign the purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem to the parameters created on the "Trigger" step.

 

 

We only need to fill the fields ‘approved’ from the fields to be updated. We need to configure the ‘approved’ field because action inputs can only be string. 

 

Choose ‘approved’ field and ‘Apply a formula’.

 

Type ‘true’ and click ‘Apply’.

 

 

Choose ‘+’ and ‘Check Condition’.

 

 

Choose the ‘Condition Editor’.

 

 

Add the following conditions and Click ‘Apply’. If PATCH method is executed successfully, the result will be empty. 

 

 

If the condition is met, the left branch of the condition executes. In the opposite case, the ‘Default’ branch of the condition executes.

 

Choose the ‘+’ on the left branch and ‘Send Response’.

 

 

Open Message Editor.

 

 

Fill the parameters as shown below and save.

 

 

You can add parameters to the title and message with the ‘<>’ button.

 

 

Do the same steps for the right branch of the condition. ‘+’ -> ’Send Response’ -> ‘Open Message Editor’

 

Fill the parameters as shown below and save.

 

 

Save, Release and Deploy just like the previous GET_PURCHASE_ORDER skill.

 

10. Launch The Joule and Test The Skills

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Environments->Joule

 

 

Launch the joule, ask for Purchase Orders and get the details.

 

 

Ask joule to approve the purchase orders and get the illustrated success message card we create.

entry.title: New Expert-Guided Implementation: Joule Prerequisites and Activation
entry.content:
Establish the Foundation for Your AI Journey 

SAP Joule is transforming how organizations interact with SAP applications by bringing intelligence directly into everyday workflows. For customers to activate Joule and unlock its AI-powered capabilities, they must first prepare their SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS), SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), and integration foundations to fully realize the value of Joule from day one. 

To support customers with this essential preparation, we are pleased to introduce a new Expert-Guided Implementation (EGI):  

Joule Prerequisites & Activation - a hands-on, expert-led program designed to help you configure all required technical components for a smooth Joule activation. 

This new offering helps customers understand Joule’s architecture, explore deployment options, configure platform prerequisites, and establish the identity and access foundation required for a secure activation. By the end of the EGI, participants will be positioned to complete all the prerequisites required to activate Joule, ensuring a seamless start to their AI adoption journey. 

 

Workshop Schedule  

To accommodate global participants, this session will be offered on the following dates and time zones as follows: 

2026 Dates 

Time 

Time Zone  

Jan 19-20 

10:00AM - 12:00PM 

EMEA | CET 

Jan 26-27

10:00AM - 12:00PM 

NA/LA | EST  

February 9-10 

10:00AM-12:00PM 

EMEA | CET 

February 16-17 

10:00AM - 12:00PM 

NA/LA | EST

March 2-3 

10:00AM - 12:00PM

EMEA | CET 

March 9-10

10:00AM-12:00PM 

NA/LA | EST

 

Why This EGI Matters 

Before Joule can be activated, customers must ensure the right technical prerequisites are in place—across SAP BTP, Cloud Identity Services, Build Work Zone, and Line-of-Business systems. This EGI provides: 

  • A clear, step-by-step path to completing these prerequisites 
  • Expert-led guidance for setting up SAP Cloud Identity Services including Identity Authentication Service (IAS)/Identity Provisioning Service (IPS), and entitlements 
  • Live configuration guidance in your SAP BTP environment and SAP Build Workzone (BWZ) 
  • Hands-on support through real examples and troubleshooting 

With AI rapidly becoming central to SAP’s product strategy, organizations need the right technical foundation to adopt Joule with confidence, security, and scalability. 

 

What You’ll Learn: Program Overview 

This 2-day EGI blends instruction, demonstrations, and guided hands-on exercises. 

Day 1 – Foundation & Architecture 

  • Understand Joule’s system architecture and deployment scenarios 
  • Learn how SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS/IPS), SAP BTP, SAP Build Work Zone, and LOB solutions work together 
  • Navigate BTP global accounts, subaccounts, entitlements, and subscriptions 
  • Validate system readiness and begin configuring your Joule environment 
  • Experience a live demonstration of Joule integrated with SAP SuccessFactors 

 

Day 2 – Identity, Provisioning & Work Zone Integration 

  • Deep-dive into SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Authentication (IAS) and Identity Provisioning (IPS) for Joule 
  • Integrate CIS with your corporate Identity Provider 
  • Configure SAP Build Workzone (BWZ) as the unified interface for Joule 
  • Establish trust relationships between systems 
  • Expose LOB content to BWZ and validate provisioning flows 

 

What You Will Achieve 

This new EGI equips your organization with everything needed to prepare for Joule activation, ensuring compliance, security, and a streamlined technical foundation from day one. 

If your organization is planning to adopt SAP Joule or preparing for AI-driven innovation within SAP applications, this EGI is the ideal starting point to fast-track your readiness and reduce implementation risk. 

By the end of the EGI, you will have: 

  • A configured SAP BTP environment with a designated Joule subaccount 
  • Completed IAS/IPS setup for secure authentication and provisioning 
  • Integrated BWZ as the experience layer for Joule 
  • Verified all activation prerequisites using a comprehensive readiness checklist 
  • Gained expert-backed confidence to run the Joule Booster and proceed with activation 

  
How to Register 
 Update the link below once the EGI is published on the Learning Hub 

 

Register here to secure your spot* today to learn from SAP experts and gain the skills to adopt and activate Joule across your enterprise. 

 * You may need to register your S-user for access to SAP Learning Hub to access the EGI registration page.  It is a one-time registration, click here.
